Today would have been Justice Ruth Bader Ginburg‚Äôs 88th birthday. This #WomensHistoryMonth, we remember her lifelong dedication to breaking down barriers as she fought to make this country more equitable for all.¬†

Today, I was proud to vote to confirm @DebHaalandNM as Secretary of @Interior. Her confirmation makes her the first Native American to serve in the Cabinet, and I am confident she will be a strong and thoughtful steward of our public lands and resources.

Today‚Äî56 years after President Johnson called for equal voting rights during a joint session of Congress‚Äîwe are still fighting for equal access to the ballot box.
 
Congress‚Äô work to protect equal voting rights isn‚Äôt done‚Äî& we should start by passing the For the People Act.

Voting rights are the foundation of our democracy. As we are seeing attacks on voting laws nationwide, it is past time for the Senate to pass the #VotingRightsAct & the For the People Act. 
 
Every option must be on the table to ensure we protect access to the ballot box. #VRAA http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1371490165504405508/img/J7LsylYjebn6mJ-R.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1371490165504405508/vid/490x270/3F-ElQaJvbtgUuH8.mp4?tag=14

RT @SenJeffMerkley Caught up with @SenAlexPadilla after his first Senate floor speech! 

Great to be on the floor to hear your speech today, and looking forward to working with you more in the Senate to deliver for working families! http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwjskYgWQAMsBjj.jpg

It was an honor to deliver my maiden speech on the Senate floor today, made all the more special by having Angela and the boys by my side for it. And of course I had some help from Diego to put the final touches on the speech. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ewj7ziDXMAE_CVD.jpg

I just voted to confirm @DebHaalandNM as our next Interior Secretary. Deb is the leader we need to advocate for tribes, champion environmental justice, and tackle the climate crisis. This is a historic day for our country.

We can‚Äôt let anything keep us from bold action and progress, including outdated rules or traditions. Too much is on the line.
 
We must end the filibuster.

The American Rescue Plan provides a lifeline for families, workers, and small businesses to survive this crisis. But our work is far from over.
 
Now is the time to lead an American comeback that leaves no working family behind.

We cannot in good conscience praise immigrant essential workers in one breath while denying them essential human dignity with the next. They have earned the rights and responsibilities of citizenship.

The reality is that there are two Californias, just as there are two Americas‚Äîone where the stock market reaches new highs for some, and one where others have to decide between buying food or paying their utility bills. We must open our eyes to these systemic inequities.

In just one generation, my family went from being immigrant cooks and house cleaners to serving in the U.S. Senate. That is the American Dream I believe in, and one I will work to keep alive for future generations.
I‚Äôm honored and humbled to be delivering my maiden speech on the floor of the U.S. Senate today. Watch live here: https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1yoKMAMRmBlKQ

From COVID relief to immigration reform‚Äîthe work we're doing in the Senate is personal to me.
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/15/us/politics/alex-padilla-immigration.html

Thank you everyone for joining tonight's town hall with Rep. Rosendale!

If the Congressman didn't get to your question tonight, please call our DC office so we can address your concerns: 202-225-3211

You can also email the congressman directly: matt.rosendale@mail.house.gov

Larry from Great Falls called in with concerns about free speech and conservatives being silenced online.

People and companies "need to be held accountable for censorship," said Rep. Rosendale.

Jennifer from Bozeman asked Rep. Rosendale about coronavirus relief for Montana farmers.

The Congressman recently cosponsored legislation addressing this issue and it remains a top priority for him.

https://twitter.com/RepRosendale/status/1365413184643993601?s=20 QT @RepRosendale Proud to be an original cosponsor of @RepHagedorn's PPP Flexibility For Farmer's and Ranchers Act.

This is smart legislation that gives farmers & ranchers flexibility as we reopen our economy and get back to normal. https://twitter.com/RepHagedorn/status/1365350720208273413

George from Laurel is an avid hunter, fisher, and camper. He just asked Rep. Rosendale about the importance of public land use.

"I completely agree," says the Congressman.

John from Great Falls asked what Rep. Rosendale is doing to help move the VA forward.

As ranking member of the @HouseVetAffairs subcommittee on Technology Modernization, the Congressman will be working hard to address this issue. 

Read more üëá
https://rosendale.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=60

https://twitter.com/RepRosendale/status/1349852032086241284?s=20 QT @RepRosendale I am cosponsoring H.J. Res. 3 which will amend the Constitution to require a balanced budget.

Adam from Billings just asked Rep. Rosendale if he still supports term limits.

Of course!

A bill implementing term limits was one of the first pieces of legislation Rosendale cosponsored after being sworn in.

https://twitter.com/RepRosendale/status/1349852031398387712?s=20 QT @RepRosendale I am cosponsoring H.J. Res. 12 which will amend the Constitution to establish term limits for members of Congress.

12/ We know these physical changes are upon us.  We know smart, capitalist market actors are going to respond to protect their investors from that risk.  It is urgent we do the analysis to understand how that will affect our financial system to protect the rest of the economy.

11/ And why @brianschatz and I introduced the related (but slightly different) Climate Change Financial Risk Act of 2019 last session.  https://casten.house.gov/media/press-releases/casten-schatz-introduce-legislation-ensure-us-financial-system-prepared-climate

10/ This is why @SenFeinstein and I introduced the Addressing Climate Financial Risk Act last month.  https://casten.house.gov/media/press-releases/casten-feinstein-introduce-bill-reduce-climate-change-risk-financial-system

9/ After all, a rapid shift from fossil fuels to renewables implicitly requires a massive write-down of assets on oil/gas/coal company balance sheets.  A shift in labor markets from coal mining to PV array installation implies big geographic shifts in economic activity

8/ These are thorny questions, but they are all the questions that we have to grapple with in a rapidly warming world.  And there are just as many financial dislocations to think about in a world that moves proactively to slow/reverse climate change.

7/ What if people start proactively moving to higher ground now?  What does that do to the local tax base?  How will schools and other local services be provided to those who can't afford / choose not to relocate?  Who will be expected to backstop that risk?

6/ Lots of property insurance programs are short duration, written one year at a time.  Will insurance companies continue to write those policies or will home owners suddenly find themselves unable to renew, leaving them (and their lenders) fully exposed?

5/ How about the property risk?  Will the home insurance policies cover the loss, or will it get punted to the National Flood Insurance program?  How much of that insured risk has been passed to the reinsurance industry?

4/ So what's the next shoe to drop?  Will it be loss of coastal properties?  If so, who will be holding the mortgages at that point?  The bank who wrote the mortgage?  The one they sold it to?  Someone who collateralized it?  Fannie and Freddie?

3/ To wit: we know massive losses of capital are coming.  What we don't know is who gets left holding the financial bag.  Local tax payers may pay for this project... but the ocean is still rising until we get climate change under control.

2/ So here's a community where parts of beaches are shrinking by 14' a year, trying to figure out whether they are willing to raise the property taxes necessary to elevate the main road.  That sisyphyean question is question is at the heart of system climate financial risk
